Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Improving Sensing and Estimation with Co-array Techniques

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Detecting targets and their direction-of-arrival plays a key role in the areas of radar, sonar, astronomy, seismology and wireless communications. In the case of passive sensing with a receiver to just analyze signals intercepted, a uniform linear sensing array with N physical sensors can identify at most N - 1 targets, guided by the theoretical limit of the so-called degree of freedom (DoF) metric. Designing a sensing system with high DoF can fundamentally advance the field of sensing, detection and estimation, by increasing the capacity of such systems. The advancement is instrumental to support various applications and services that are important for national security and the economy. This project seeks to develop some fundamental techniques for active sensing to significantly increase the degree-of-freedom metric, and contribute to the advancement of sensing, detection and estimation that many applications depend upon. The investigator will incorporate the project materials into both undergraduate and graduate courses, and will facilitate participation from under-represented groups.<br/><br/>The work falls into two major thrusts: 1) Developing a fundamental Active Synthetic Co-array that can exploit the concurrent use of principles of MIMO radar and co-arrays to surpass the sensing limit from the use of either technique alone; 2) Designing a novel two-level advanced sparse array geometry that can take full advantage of the active synthetic co-array method and flexibly integrate different array geometries in the two levels to increase the DoF up to four orders while meeting various application needs with different array structures.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Detecting targets and their direction-of-arrival (DOA) plays a key role in the areas of radar, sonar, astronomy, seismology and wireless communications. In the case of passive sensing with a receiver to just analyze signals intercepted, a uniform linear array with N physical sensors can identify at most N - 1 targets, with its degree of freedom (DoF) limited to N-1.  As DoF serves as a theoretical upper bound on the number of targets that can be detected, providing a sensing system with high DoF can fundamentally advance the field of sensing, detection and estimation. The advancement is instrumental to support various applications and services that are important for national security and economy. This project concurrently exploits the principles of multi-input multi-output (MIMO) radar and co-array to significantly increase DoF and break through the sensing limit from the use of each alone. Built upon this fundamental technique, the project will further design two-level advanced sparse array geometries to increase the DoF up to four order, while flexibly incorporating various array geometries to meet different application needs.  

We have completed two major tasks in this project.

 

 1.                  High Performance DOA Estimation Exploiting Synthetic Sum-and-Difference Co-arrays in Active Co-prime Arrays and Nested Arrays: We propose a new approach to accomplish the direction of arrival (DOA) estimation for mono-static multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) radar system. We make two major contributions to the existing MIMO radar system. We first propose an active synthetic co-array (ASC) method, the sum-and-difference co-array of the sum co-array (SDCSC), that incorporates the co-array techniques commonly proposed for passive sparse array into the active MIMO radar system. The proposed ASC approach can significantly improve the DoF and break through the limit on DoF from the aperture of the virtual MIMO array. We provide a theoretical proof that our proposed ASC method can achieve 6MN + M - 2N - 1 DoFs in co-prime arrays and 3N1N2 + N1 + 3N2 - 3 DoFs in nested arrays respectively. Compared with MIMO radar systems that employ the difference co-array of the sum co-array (DCSC), our proposed approach can nearly double the achievable DoFs. The second contribution is that we propose a preliminary array geometry design of the the physical MIMO array structure, the 2-level nested array (2NA), that can achieve O(N^4) DoFs with O(N) physical sensors with our proposed ASC approach. Simulation results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our proposed approach in achieving high performance DOA estimation.

2.                  DOA Estimation with 2-Layer Sparse Arrays in Active MIMO Radars: We propose a new approach to accomplish the direction of arrival (DOA) estimation for mono-static multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) radar system.  We first present an active synthetic co-array (ASC) approach which combines the active MIMO radar system with the passive sparse array sensing techniques. When directly applying ASC approach to the existing sparse arrays, we can achieve O(N^2) DoFs with O(N) physical sensors. We further provide a fundamental geometry design of the physical MIMO arrays, the 2-layer sparse arrays, that can take full advantage of the ASC approach to significantly improve the DoF from O(N^2) to O(N^4). We propose and analyze several fundamental 2-layer sparse array (2LSA) geometry designs of the MIMO radar system that can achieve O(N^4) DoFs with O(N) physical antennas when applying our proposed ASC approach. We provide close-form expressions of our proposed 2LSA geometries and the corresponding achievable number of DoFs. Simulation results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our proposed approach in achieving high performance DOA. It can significantly outperforms that of the other traditional 1-layer arrays, while enjoying the flexibility in array configuration to provide different tradeoffs of complexity and performance.

We have trained one PhD students and incorporated the principle of coprime design into the courses Wireless Communications and Wireless Networks. We also contribute to developing the vision for future detection and communications.
